commentary.line: That concludes proceedings from this game. Looking forward to your company tomorrow as New Zealand take on Scotland at Dunedin. This is Ramakrishnan, signing off on behalf of Akshay, Sidhant, Raju, Krishna and Bhanu. Goodbye!
Alviro Petersen: Ireland produced a performance of the highest standard, and beat West Indies in the #WC2015
Glenn McGrath: A great win by @Irelandcricket over the @westindies A brilliant effort to chase down 304 & did it with 4 overs to go #CWC15
Trent Johnston: Certainly not a shock or upset from this group of players. Warm up games are just that. Enjoy the celebrations as I know you can and will.
Harsha Bhogle: Ireland win. Not an upset.
Mohandas Menon: Pakistan at Kingston by 3 wkts in WC2007 England at Bangalore by 3 wkts in WC2011 #WIvIre #CWC15
Here are a few tweets:

What a win for Ireland! When the ICC announced that the 2015 World Cup would be contested only among 10 teams, Ireland were not happy and they appealed to the cricket governing body to allow the associates-affiliates as well. Boy, they have justified their inclusion today and played some fantastic cricket for most of the match.

Porterfield: "It's obviously a fantastic win. The way we went about chasing those runs was great. It sets us up nicely for the next few games, so it's a great position to be in. We thoroughly believed in ourselves that we can chase this down. We've just got to continue that in the tournament. They obviously had a strong finish there. 300 was probably about par, we knew it was a good pitch. We knew it was well within our grasp and we just needed to lay that platform. The batsmen were fantastic. Most definitely (when asked if Ireland can qualify for the quarters). We are going to play in completely different conditions in the next game, it tends to be quicker and bouncier at Brisbane."

Holder: "It was a tough loss. We backed ourselves to defend 300, but we didn't defend today. It was a good partnership between Simmons and Sammy, we were struggling in the middle overs and they came in, added impetus to the innings and got us to 300. We tried to be a lot more specific in terms of our powerplay overs and our death bowling at the end. We didn't get wickets today. I think we just need to be more precise when we set the field and just stick to the fields which we set. We are leaking too many boundaries. So I think we just need to tighten up there and we'd be a lot better off in the games to come."

Stirling: "Great to win that first game in the competition and hopefully we can make it two from two in a few days from now. I was happy with my innings. I owed the guys 90 runs after dropping Sammy on nought, so it was nice to get a few. I think it was a good toss to win. We got early wickets and the pitch got better and better as the day went on, thankfully we chased it."
Paul Stirling is the Man of the Match

Ireland were superb with the bat. They have shown to the world that the tag of 'minnows' is not for them. They keep producing such good performances. They knocked out Pakistan in the 2007 World Cup and defeated England in 2011 as well. West Indies are their newest prey and this is just the start of the tournament. Their win today opens up the group even more. The fourth quarter-final spot from this group could well be decided between Ireland and Zimbabwe, instead of the West Indies.

Earlier in the day, West Indies lost 3 wickets in a space of 14 balls and were tottering at 87/5 at one stage. However, Sammy and Simmons then got together and put on a 154-run stand for the 6th wicket. Sammy registered his highest ODI score and missed out on a century by 11 runs. Simmons, however, went onto score his 2nd ODI ton and helped his team to go past 300. He was well supported by Russell, who chipped in with a 13-ball 27. The Irish bowlers, who were magnificent at the start and the middle, lost their line and lengths during the death overs. Ireland conceded 124 runs in the last 10 overs and were taken to the cleaners by the West Indian batsmen. As it turns out, it wasn't enough for Holder and Co. to win.

Ireland have done extremely well to chase this mammoth total down. After taking a drubbing in the final few overs while bowling, the Irish batters started off brilliantly. Porterfield and Stirling were very good, putting on 71 for the first wicket. However, even after their captain Porterfield departed, Stirling and Ed Joyce batted aggressively, adding 106 for the second wicket in just 86 balls. Unfortunately, Stirling got out in the nineties and the way he batted, he deserved a century. Niall O'Brien then joined Ed Joyce at the crease and both of them thrashed Holder's bowlers to all parts of the park. They put on 96 runs together in just 11.3 overs, before Ed Joyce departed for 84. Even though the West Indies managed to pick up 3 more wickets in quick succession after that, Niall O'Brien made sure that there were no more hiccups and saw his team through. He himself finished with 79 off 60 balls.

Mooney jumps in joy and hugs O'Brien. The Ireland players come onto the field and shake hands with their opponents. There has been a good support for the Ireland team today at Nelson and their fans are joyous.

45.5   Jerome Taylor to J Mooney, FOUR, That's it! It was Pakistan in 2007, England in 2011 and now it's West Indies in 2015. Ireland become the first team to successfully chase down a total in this World Cup. This is the fifth time in World Cup history that a target in excess of 300 has been achieved and Ireland have three of those to their credit. Coming back to the ball, it was a short ball on the stumps, Mooney tries to pull, he was surprised by the pace on the ball as it came quickly onto him, the ball takes the top edge and flies over the keeper's head
45.4   Jerome Taylor to J Mooney, no run, low full toss outside off stump, punched to mid-off
The Ireland dug-out is ready to erupt! Interestingly, there is a man at slip.
45.3   Jerome Taylor to N O'Brien, 1 run, driven hard, but Simmons runs quickly to his right at long-off and keeps them down to one
45.2   Jerome Taylor to J Mooney, 1 run, back of a length hurrying onto Mooney, who hops and tucks it to mid-wicket
45.1   Jerome Taylor to J Mooney, no run, short of length delivery outside off stump, Mooney looks to run it down to the third man but misses
Ireland are just a hit away now and their fans are ecstatic in the stands.

44.5   Roach to J Mooney, 1 run, a lazy effort from Gayle and he fumbles the ball at cover, they get a run. Short of a length delivery just outside off stump, Mooney taps it gently, Gayle tries to fetch it with his right hand but misses
44.4   Roach to N O'Brien, 1 run, taps this into the on-side and sets off for a quick single
44.3   Roach to N O'Brien, FOUR, that's an authoritative shot. Full and outside off stump, O'Brien drives well over extra-cover and it rockets to the boundary. He's doing it easily

44.1   Roach to N O'Brien, out K O'Brien Run Out!! 1 run completed. The younger brother is late to respond for the second run and he's run-out for a duck. Slower ball wide outside off stump, Niall drives it to deep point, Smith runs to his right and fires an accurate throw adjacent to the stumps at the bowler's end. Roach stays calm and whips the bails off before Kevin made his ground. K O'Brien run out (Dwayne Smith/Roach) 0(1)
Roach to N O'Brien, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!
Run-out check has been sent upstairs. Kevin O'Brien is in trouble and he's OUT! Is there a twist in the tale?
43.6   Jerome Taylor to K O'Brien, no run, full delivery on the off stump, dug out to mid-wicket
Kevin O'Brien, right handed bat, comes to the crease

43.5   Jerome Taylor to G Wilson, out Caught by Gayle!! A soft dismissal and West Indies are hardly celebrating. Full and outside off stump, in the slot to be put away, Wilson doesn't control the drive and hits in the air, Gayle moves his hands to his left at cover and reverse-cups the ball easily in the end. G Wilson c Gayle b Jerome Taylor 1(6)
Jerome Taylor to G Wilson, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

43.3   Jerome Taylor to N O'Brien, 1 run, short of length delivery angling into the left-hander, defended to point
O'Brien wants a change of bat.

Kemar Roach [4.0-0-38-0] is back into the attack
41.6   Jerome Taylor to G Wilson, no run, full and on the leg stump, defended to mid-on

Gary Wilson, right handed bat, comes to the crease

41.3   Jerome Taylor to Balbirnie, out Caught by Darren Bravo!! Short ball and he holes out. Balbirnie pulls, but doesn't get the connection right, hits it in the air and deep square leg just moves to his right to take an easy catch. That's the second catch for Bravo today. Balbirnie c Darren Bravo b Jerome Taylor 9(9) [4s-2]
Jerome Taylor to Balbirnie, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
41.2   Jerome Taylor to Balbirnie, no run, shortish delivery outside off stump, cut to point

Ireland need just 22 runs off 60 balls and it's just a matter of time for them.

39.6   Jerome Taylor to Balbirnie, FOUR, oh no! One more slower ball full and in the slot, coach Curtly Ambrose is going to be severe on the West Indies bowlers I guess, Balbirnie just punches it off the front foot to the left of cover

39.5   Jerome Taylor to Balbirnie, FOUR, the boundaries are flowing out there. How many times do I write that a West Indies bowler bowls a fullish slower ball, the result is evident, this time a cover drive timed to perfection

39.2   Jerome Taylor to Ed Joyce, out Caught by Darren Bravo!! That's hit in the air and straight to the fielder. Full and wide outside off stump, Ed Joyce looks to drive hard, he almost slices it, the ball goes flat, it was timed well but he picked out the fielder at sweeper cover. End of a sensational innings. He gets a great applause as he walks back. He raises his bat to acknowledge the applause. Ed Joyce c Darren Bravo b Jerome Taylor 84(67) [4s-10 6s-2]
Jerome Taylor to Ed Joyce, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

39.1   Jerome Taylor to Ed Joyce, FOUR, the boundaries don't seem to stop. Taylor looks for a widish yorker, but Ed Joyce out-thinks him by opening the face of the bat at the last moment and squeezes it fine to the third man boundary
Ireland have stolen 25 runs off the 12 balls.

38.4   J Holder to N O'Brien, FOUR, over the top again and four more! Oh come on! Ask them to stop feeding the batsman. Full and outside off stump, O'Brien lofts it flat over mid-off. Maybe they needed a Mohammad Irfan at mid-off, as a few of the boundaries have just about managed to clear the fielder inside the ring
38.3   J Holder to Ed Joyce, 1 run, Ed Joyce nudges this to square leg, looks for the second, but the fielder rushed in quickly

38.1   J Holder to N O'Brien, FOUR, 13th ODI fifty, this has come off just 38 balls and what a hand he's played. Full and in the slot, this is unacceptable from West Indies. After scoring a hundred, Simmons said in the innings break that the slower balls aren't stopping on the batsman, the West Indies bowlers seem to have misread the pitch. They continue to take pace off the ball and bowl full, a set batsman like O'Brien doesn't miss out on those juicy balls and he muscles it over mid-off and it's almost a maximum
Eleven runs off the over and the equation is down to just 50 runs needed off 72 balls.

37.2   Jerome Taylor to N O'Brien, FOUR, and he's hurting them straightaway! Full and outside off stump, not sure if this is the right length at this stage, O'Brien lofts the drive, mid-off jumps high but it just evades him

37.1   Jerome Taylor to N O'Brien, 2 runs, oh no! The West Indies captain drops a vital catch. Nothing is working for them on the field! Slower delivery from Taylor, O'Brien mistimes the slog high in the air, mid-on runs to his left, gets both hands to it, but the ball hits the fingertips and goes down to ground. Holder is livid with himself as he throws the ball back

Batting powerplay has been enforced.

Drinks are on the field now. Ireland are cruising now. Stirling was brilliant and deserved a century, but got out trying to push one into the off-side. He was given good company by Joyce, who has motored to 76 off just 59 balls. Niall O'Brien has given him great support. Ireland are the favourites to win this now. Can the West Indies pull things back? Let's find out.

34.6   Gayle to N O'Brien, 2 runs, dropped! Another tossed up delivery on off, O'Brien goes for the lofted drive inside-out over cover, but doesn't get the proper elevation, Holder at cover jumps in the air and gets a hand on it, but can't hold onto it. The batsmen take a couple as the ball dribbles away to the deep

West Indies needed that wicket to stay in the game. That also ends a brilliant 106-run stand. Stirling c Ramdin b Samuels 92(84) [4s-9 6s-3]

West Indies can't find the right bowling combination right now. Samuels now comes into the attack.

Time for the players to sip on some drinks. Ireland have started off superbly. Porterfield and Stirling came out with a positive mindset and kept up with the required run-rate, the latter also registered his fifty. It will be trouble for West Indies, if they allow the Irish to keep going in the same way.

Welcome back.. Ireland had the match in their grasp before they let Simmons and Sammy take it away from them. However, they still have a chance to make a match of it. Porterfield on strike. Holder has two slips in place...
The momentum is with West Indies. It will be interesting to see Ireland's approach with the bat. Take a break and join us back in a while.

Simmons: "It was a good innings, I feel good about myself. We needed that partnership, it didn't happen early on, but me and Sammy batted well and we put on a partnership. It's a good batting wicket, the slower ball hasn't been stopping and is sliding. It's a new role for me, batting lower down the order, normally I am an opening batsman, but I accept the challenge. We have better swing bowlers and hopefully they can utilise the pitch."

Sammy was struggling with his back but he hit 89 valuable runs, before being dismissed. Simmons carried on and scored his second ODI hundred. Russell too played a handy cameo to push the West Indies score past 300. The Ireland spinners bowled 26 overs and conceded 109 runs, while the pacers leaked 194 runs. McBrine bowled very well for 10-1-26-0, but Dockrell was the pick of the bowlers with figures of 3/50.

Earlier, after opting to bowl, Ireland put immense pressure on the West Indies batsmen with disciplined bowling. Smith threw away a start and Gayle, despite getting his eye in, couldn't get going. He took 54 balls to hit a maximum. Ireland captain Porterfield employed spinners and they stemmed the run flow. West Indies lost their way in the middle, but Simmons and Sammy, after spending some time, played their shots to transfer the pressure back onto the Ireland bowlers. Once both were set, it was hard work for the bowlers as they scored boundaries at will.

From 87/5, West Indies have recovered well to post 304. When Dockrell removed Gayle, Samuels and Ramdin in a space of 8 balls, things weren't looking great for Holder and Co. but Simmons and Sammy combined very well to share a 154-run counter-attacking stand to swing the pendulum back in West Indies' favour.

Drinks are on the field now. West Indies were reeling at 87/5, but these two have combined well to share a brisk 76-run stand. The Ireland spinners troubled them early on, but as they spent more time in the middle, they played some free-flowing shots. Ireland would be desperate to break this stand. Otherwise, they could well be chasing over 250.

Samuels has been given out lbw. He has decided to review the decision. Dockrell's front foot is fine. It pitches in line and even if it's clipping leg, it will be given out. The height is not a problem. There's no inside edge on that and let's wait for the Hawk-Eye. The umpire is however taking a lot of time to check the edge. Hawk-Eye shows that it is hitting leg and the onfield decision is upheld. Samuels has to go.

The teams line-up for the anthems. The Irish gather around in a huddle after the national anthems. The West Indies openers make their way out to the middle. Smith, playing his 100th ODI will take strike. Here we go..

Pitch Report: "A beautiful part of the world. This is one of the better pitches I have seen for a long time. It's got grass on it, but it's an even covering. Speaking to the groundsmen and his team, they feel this will go through, there will be a little bit of bounce and little bit of pace as well. I don't see it turning. The ball will come onto the bat. A lot of runs to be scored on this wicket," reckons Ian Botham
Teams:
West Indies (Playing XI): Chris Gayle, Dwayne Smith, Darren Bravo, Marlon Samuels, Denesh Ramdin(w), Lendl Simmons, Darren Sammy, Andre Russell, Jason Holder(c), Jerome Taylor, Kemar Roach
Ireland (Playing XI): William Porterfield(c), Paul Stirling, Ed Joyce, Niall O'Brien, Andrew Balbirnie, Gary Wilson(w), Kevin O'Brien, John Mooney, Max Sorensen, George Dockrell, Andy McBrine

Porterfield: "We have a good blend in the squad. Few lads are playing their first World Cup, while few are playing their third. We will have a bowl. We have been here for a couple of days and it swung around a bit in the nets and we can utilize that upfront. I think you got to target every game, but every game is a two point game."

Holder: "It is a great thrill to lead my country. It is a wonderful cricket stadium. I would have liked to bowl as well. Seems to have a bit of grass and having said that we have to bat and put some runs on the board. Benn is struggling this morning, we left him out. We brought in the extra seamer in Kemar Roach. Yeah not too worried about him (Gayle), backing him to give 100 percent today."
Ireland have won the toss and have opted to field

Hello and welcome to the 5th game of the World Cup. All the previous 4 games saw teams scoring 300 and above batting first. Will the trend continue? We will find out soon. But before that, toss and teams will come your way in a little while from now. Stay tuned.
Ireland

Ireland won the Dubai Triangular tournament prior to the warm-up games, a tournament that had Scotland and Afghanistan as the other two teams. However, in their first warm-up game, Scotland defeated Ireland by a mammoth margin of 179 runs, after the Scots posted 296 batting first. The Irish batting never got going and folded for just 117. In their second warm-up game, they were a different outfit altogether, winning by 4 wickets against Bangladesh. Mooney and Sorensen were superb with the ball on that occasion and were the chief architects of the win. They can surely defeat any team on their day.

Talking about Ireland, the team might not be expected to reach the quarter-finals, but they have the firepower to cause an upset. Led by William Porterfield, the Irish team consists of match-winners like Kevin O'Brien, who can take the game away from the opposition single-handedly. Apart from Kevin, his brother Niall can also pack a punch. Their all-rounders lower down the order can be very handy as well.
West Indies

West Indies last played in South Africa and lost the ODI series 4-1. They were beaten comprehensively. Looking back at their warm-ups, they were thumped by England, after they were bowled out for a paltry 122. In their second game against Scotland, they went onto score 313 batting first. However, they were lucky to win the game by 3 runs as Scotland lost 4 wickets in 7 runs to finish at 310/9. Their bowling doesn't look threatening and they might find it difficult against the big teams.

West Indies enter the tournament with two big names missing from their squad - Dwayne Bravo and Kieron Pollard. Both of them were important members of the squad before the World Cup squad was announced, but unfortunately a rift with the West Indies board meant they were ignored for this tournament. Apart from that, Sunil Narine pulled out of the World Cup squad, seeking more time to rectify his bowling action.
Let's take a look at the form and composition of both the teams.

Even though West Indies will enter the game as favorites, they will be wary of the Irish challenge, especially after their heroics against England in the 2011 World Cup. West Indies might have big names like Chris Gayle, Marlon Samuels and Kemar Roach in their squad, but if they don't fire, they will be in deep trouble.

South Africa, India and Pakistan are the three teams everyone expects in the quarter-finals of the World Cup. We could well get an idea of who would take the fourth quarters spot from Pool B today. West Indies usually would be the favorites to go through as the fourth team, but with Ireland and Zimbabwe playing well, it could well prove out to be a 3-way fight.

Preview:

Let's go back in time a bit. February 19, 2014 was the date for the West Indies-Ireland T20 encounter in Jamaica. The Caribbean team, winner at the T20 World Cup in 2012, failed to get going and was restricted to 116 for 8, after which the Irish fashioned a six-wicket win in the last over.

Cut to the 2015 World Cup, and both teams are ready again for Monday's Pool B encounter at Nelson. The chances of an Irish upset are greater than they were in Jamaica, even if it's a different format. What gives Ireland a lot of heart is West Indies' recent form. Jason Holder's men in the run-up to the tournament suffered a 4-1 ODI defeat to South Africa and then in both their warm-ups they gave a poor account of themselves. Against England, all they could manage was 122 and lost the match by nine wickets with 27.1 overs still to spare and against Scotland, they barely won: the victory margin of three runs despite scoring 313 for 9 spoke a great deal about how unconvincing their bowling was.

Ireland weren't much convincing either in their warm-ups. They lost to Scotland by 179 runs after getting bowled out for a lowly 117, but then they upset a Test-playing nation in Bangladesh as they chased down 190. If not their upset victory in 2014, the one against Bangladesh will surely give Ireland a lot of confidence.

Ireland's chances of reaching the quarter-finals are next to impossible but they know that they can upset the apple carts of a few teams. West Indies are one of the vulnerable Test-playing nations and Ireland know that too. However, Holder wasn't too worried."They are not to be under-estimated but having said that, we are very confident," he said on Sunday.

"Obviously you go through tough times in your cricket and you just move on and take whatever you can from it.

"We're starting a new campaign and I think it's important that we all put our minds on it and just go out and play some good cricket for West Indies. We'll start from ball one and go out and play some hard, aggressive cricket."

If you thought that was confidence, hear out Ireland captain William Porterfield. "I don't think it will be a surprise. We've played enough cricket now and everyone knows everyone. There are not many teams that won't know much about the 15 lads who are in our squad," he said.

Clearly, both teams are fancying themselves on the high-scoring pitch at Nelson, but looking at the 4-0 ODI head-to-head in West Indies' favour (including two World Cup wins), there are no prizes for guessing as to who is heading into the match as favourites.
Teams:

West Indies (From): Dwayne Smith, Chris Gayle, Darren Bravo, Marlon Samuels, Lendl Simmons, Denesh Ramdin(w), Darren Sammy, Andre Russell, Jason Holder(c), Jerome Taylor, Kemar Roach, Nikita Miller, Sheldon Cottrell, Jonathan Carter, Sulieman Benn

Ireland (From): William Porterfield(c), Paul Stirling, Ed Joyce, Gary Wilson(w), Niall O'Brien, Andrew Balbirnie, Kevin O'Brien, John Mooney, George Dockrell, Max Sorensen, Craig Young, Alex Cusack, Peter Chase, Stuart Thompson, Andy McBrine
